snippet: The declines, which follow a decrease that began shortly after the murders of two patrol officers in Brooklyn, may present a new challenge for Mayor Bill de Blasio and Police Commissioner William J. Bratton.
abstract: New York City police cut back sharply on arrests and summonses for second consecutive week, magnifying conflict between department and Mayor Bill de Blasio; force issues 347 criminal summonses, down from 4,077 one year earlier, and parking and traffic tickets drop by 90 percent; trend increases pressure on mayor and Police Commissioner William J Bratton, who acknowledges sagging morale at department amid protests and murder of two patrol officers in Brooklyn.

byline.original: By J. DAVID GOODMAN and AL BAKER

lead_paragraph: The declines, which follow a decrease that began shortly after the murders of two patrol officers in Brooklyn, may present a new challenge for Mayor Bill de Blasio and Police Commissioner William J. Bratton.

headline.main: For Second Week, Arrests Plunge in New York City
headline.print_headline: For a 2nd Week, Arrests Plunge in New York City
